001package io.github.ai4ci.abm.inhost;
002
003import java.io.Serializable;
004
005import org.apache.commons.lang3.tuple.Pair;
006import org.immutables.value.Value;
007
008import io.github.ai4ci.abm.inhost.ImmutableInHostMarkovState.Builder;
009import io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost.MarkovStateModel;
010import io.github.ai4ci.util.Sampler;
011
012/**
013 * A discrete-time Markov chain model of in-host disease and symptom
014 * progression.
015 *
016 * <p>
017 * This model tracks two independent state machines:
018 * <ul>
019 * <li><b>Disease state</b>: SUSCEPTIBLE → EXPOSED → INFECTIOUS → IMMUNE,</li>
020 * <li><b>Symptom state</b>: ASYMPTOMATIC → SYMPTOMATIC → HOSPITALISED →
021 * DEAD.</li>
022 * </ul>
023 *
024 * <p>
025 * Transitions are governed by daily probabilities defined in
026 * {@link InHostMarkovStateMachine}. The model assumes binary immunity: once
027 * immune, individuals are fully protected unless waning occurs.
028 *
029 * <p>
030 * The viral load, severity, and immune activity are derived from the current
031 * state, enabling integration with transmission and calibration modules. This
032 * approach sacrifices biological detail for computational efficiency and direct
033 * mapping to observable epidemiological rates (e.g., IFR, HFR).
034 *
035 * @see InHostMarkovStateMachine
036 * @see <a href=
037 *      "https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/93852/sum-of-bernoulli-variables-with-different-success-probabilities">Poisson
038 *      Binomial Distribution</a>
039 */
040@Value.Immutable
041public interface InHostMarkovState extends InHostModelState<MarkovStateModel> {
042
043        /**
044         * The disease progression states in the Markov model.
045         *
046         * <p>
047         * States evolve as: \[ \text{SUSCEPTIBLE} \xrightarrow{p_{\text{inf}}}
048         * \text{EXPOSED} \xrightarrow{p_{\text{inf→inf}}} \text{INFECTIOUS}
049         * \xrightarrow{p_{\text{rec}}} \text{IMMUNE} \xrightarrow{p_{\text{waning}}}
050         * \text{SUSCEPTIBLE} \] where transitions are governed by daily
051         * probabilities. Immunity is assumed to be complete while active.
052         */
053        public static enum DiseaseState {
054                /**
055                 * The individual is susceptible to infection and has no immunity. They
056                 * can transition to EXPOSED if exposed to infectious virions, or to
057                 * IMMUNE if immunized (e.g., vaccinated). This state represents the
058                 * baseline risk of infection.
059                 */
060                SUSCEPTIBLE,
061                /**
062                 * The individual has been exposed to infectious virions but is not yet
063                 * infectious. They can transition to INFECTIOUS with probability \(
064                 * p_{\text{inf→inf}} \) or, in some models, back to SUSCEPTIBLE if the
065                 * exposure does not lead to infection. This state captures the incubation
066                 * period before viral shedding begins.
067                 */
068                EXPOSED,
069                /**
070                 * The individual is actively infectious and can transmit the virus to
071                 * others. They can transition to IMMUNE upon recovery or, in some models,
072                 * back to SUSCEPTIBLE if immunity wanes. This state represents the period
073                 * of active infection and viral shedding.
074                 */
075                INFECTIOUS,
076                /**
077                 * The individual has recovered from infection and is temporarily immune.
078                 * They can transition back to SUSCEPTIBLE if immunity wanes. This state
079                 * represents the post-infection period of protection against reinfection.
080                 */
081                IMMUNE
082
083        }
084
085        // these next 3 are here because there is no easy way to access them within
086        // the top level experiment configuration outside of the config stage so
087        // we have to copy them.
088
089        /**
090         * Defines the transition probabilities for the Markov chain model of disease
091         * and symptom progression.
092         *
093         * <p>
094         * This component encapsulates all time-homogeneous transition rates between
095         * states. It enables calibration from epidemiological data (e.g., duration
096         * of infectiousness, case fatality rate).
097         *
098         * <p>
099         * The probability of becoming symptomatic is computed as: \[ p_s = 1 - (1 -
100         * r_c)^{1/D} \] where \( r_c \) is the infection-case rate and \( D \) is
101         * the average duration of infection, ensuring that over the full infectious
102         * period, the cumulative probability of symptoms is \( r_c \).
103         *
104         * @see #getPAsymptomaticSymptomatic()
105         */
106        @Value.Immutable
107        public static interface InHostMarkovStateMachine extends Serializable {
108
109                /**
110                 * Returns the daily probability of transitioning from asymptomatic to
111                 * symptomatic, calibrated to achieve the target infection-case rate over
112                 * the infectious period.
113                 *
114                 * <p>
115                 * If \( r_c \) is the desired case rate and \( D \) is the average
116                 * duration of infectiousness, then: \[ p_s = 1 - (1 - r_c)^{1/D} \] This
117                 * ensures that the probability of ever becoming symptomatic during
118                 * infection is \( r_c \), under the assumption of independent daily risk.
119                 *
120                 * <p>
121                 * This formulation assumes each day presents an independent chance of
122                 * symptom onset, and the overall process resembles a <i>geometric
123                 * trial</i> or a sum of Bernoulli variables with equal probability — a
124                 * special case of the Poisson binomial distribution.
125                 *
126                 * @return daily probability of symptom onset given infectiousness
127                 */
128                double getPAsymptomaticSymptomatic();
129
130                /**
131                 * Returns the daily probability of transitioning from EXPOSED to
132                 * INFECTIOUS.
133                 *
134                 * @return the daily probability of an exposed individual becoming
135                 *         infectious
136                 */
137                double getPExposedInfectious();
138                // double getPExposedSusceptible();
139
140                /**
141                 * Returns the daily probability of transitioning from HOSPITALISED to
142                 * ASYMPTOMATIC (recovery), calibrated to achieve the target hospital
143                 * recovery rate over the course of hospitalisation.
144                 *
145                 * @return the daily probability of recovery from hospitalisation,
146                 *         calibrated to match target hospital recovery rates
147                 */
148                double getPHospitalisedAsymptomatic();
149
150                /**
151                 * Returns the daily probabilities of transitioning from HOSPITALISED to
152                 * DEAD, and from HOSPITALISED to ASYMPTOMATIC (recovery), calibrated to
153                 * achieve the target hospital fatality rate (HFR) and recovery rate over
154                 * the course of hospitalisation.
155                 *
156                 * @return the daily probabilities of death and recovery from
157                 *         hospitalisation, calibrated to match target HFR and recovery
158                 *         rates
159                 */
160                double getPHospitalisedDead();
161
162                /**
163                 * Returns the daily probability of transitioning from IMMUNE to
164                 * SUSCEPTIBLE due to waning immunity.
165                 *
166                 * @return the daily probability of waning immunity (IMMUNE → SUSCEPTIBLE)
167                 */
168                double getPImmuneSusceptible();
169
170                /**
171                 * Returns the daily probability of transitioning from INFECTIOUS to
172                 * IMMUNE, and from IMMUNE to SUSCEPTIBLE.
173                 *
174                 * @return the daily probability of recovery (INFECTIOUS → IMMUNE) and
175                 *         waning immunity (IMMUNE → SUSCEPTIBLE)
176                 */
177                double getPInfectiousImmune();
178
179                /**
180                 * Returns the daily probabilities of transitions from symptomatic and
181                 * hospitalised states to less severe or more severe states, calibrated to
182                 * match population-level outcomes (e.g., IFR, HFR).
183                 *
184                 * @return the daily probabilities of symptom progression and regression,
185                 *         including recovery and death, conditioned on current symptom
186                 *         state
187                 */
188                double getPSymptomaticAsymptomatic();
189
190                /**
191                 * Returns the daily probabilities of transitioning from SYMPTOMATIC to
192                 * DEAD, and from HOSPITALISED to DEAD, calibrated to achieve the target
193                 * infection-fatality rate (IFR) and hospital fatality rate (HFR) over the
194                 * course of the disease.
195                 *
196                 * @return the daily probabilities of death from symptomatic and
197                 *         hospitalised states, calibrated to match target IFR and HFR
198                 */
199                double getPSymptomaticDead();
200
201                /**
202                 * Returns the daily probability of transitioning from SYMPTOMATIC to
203                 * HOSPITALISED, and from SYMPTOMATIC to DEAD.
204                 *
205                 * @return the daily probabilities of worsening symptoms leading to
206                 *         hospitalisation or death
207                 */
208                double getPSymptomaticHospitalised();
209
210                /**
211                 * Updates the disease state using daily Bernoulli trials.
212                 *
213                 * <p>
214                 * Transitions:
215                 * <ul>
216                 * <li>EXPOSED → INFECTIOUS with probability \( p_{\text{inf}} \),</li>
217                 * <li>INFECTIOUS → IMMUNE with probability \( p_{\text{rec}} \),</li>
218                 * <li>IMMUNE → SUSCEPTIBLE with probability \( p_{\text{waning}} \).</li>
219                 * </ul>
220                 *
221                 * <p>
222                 * The use of independent Bernoulli draws aligns with the discrete-time
223                 * survival framework. When aggregating over a population, the number of
224                 * individuals transitioning follows a <i>Poisson binomial
225                 * distribution</i> with: \[ \mathbb{E}[N_{\text{transitions}}] = \sum_i
226                 * p_i, \quad \mathrm{Var}(N_{\text{transitions}}) = \sum_i p_i(1 - p_i)
227                 * \] as referenced in the knowledge base.
228                 *
229                 * @param current the current disease state
230                 * @param rng     the random sampler
231                 * @return the next disease state
232                 */
233                default DiseaseState updateDiseaseState(
234                                DiseaseState current, Sampler rng
235                ) {
236                        switch (current) {
237                        case EXPOSED:
238                                return rng
239                                                .bern(this.getPExposedInfectious(), DiseaseState.INFECTIOUS
240                                                // This is disabled because partial transmission is handles
241                                                // before an
242                                                // individual gets exposed. It is a fundamental part of the
243                                                // contact process
244                                                // and in this model immunity is binary and a disease state so
245                                                // we don't get a path from exposed to susceptible because of
246                                                // that.
247                                                // return rng.multinom(
248                                                // Pair.of(this.getPExposedInfectious(),
249                                                // DiseaseState.INFECTIOUS) ,
250                                                // Pair.of(this.getPExposedSusceptible(),
251                                                // DiseaseState.SUSCEPTIBLE)
252                                                ).orElse(DiseaseState.EXPOSED);
253
254                        case INFECTIOUS:
255                                return rng.bern(this.getPInfectiousImmune(), DiseaseState.IMMUNE)
256                                                .orElse(DiseaseState.INFECTIOUS);
257                        case IMMUNE:
258                                return rng
259                                                .bern(this.getPImmuneSusceptible(), DiseaseState.SUSCEPTIBLE)
260                                                .orElse(DiseaseState.IMMUNE);
261                        case SUSCEPTIBLE:
262                                return DiseaseState.SUSCEPTIBLE;
263                        default:
264                                throw new RuntimeException();
265                        }
266                }
267
268                /**
269                 * Updates the symptom state using multinomial transitions conditioned on
270                 * disease state.
271                 *
272                 * <p>
273                 * For example, from SYMPTOMATIC, the individual may:
274                 * <ul>
275                 * <li>Recover → ASYMPTOMATIC,</li>
276                 * <li>Worsen → HOSPITALISED,</li>
277                 * <li>Deteriorate → DEAD.</li>
278                 * </ul>
279                 *
280                 * <p>
281                 * The multinomial draw ensures only one transition occurs per day. The
282                 * probabilities are calibrated to reproduce population-level outcomes
283                 * (e.g., IFR) over time.
284                 *
285                 * @param current the current symptom state
286                 * @param dx      the current disease state (used to gate symptom onset)
287                 * @param rng     the random sampler
288                 * @return the next symptom state
289                 */
290                default SymptomState updateSymptomState(
291                                SymptomState current, DiseaseState dx, Sampler rng
292                ) {
293                        switch (current) {
294                        case ASYMPTOMATIC:
295                                if (dx.equals(DiseaseState.INFECTIOUS)) return rng.bern(
296                                                this.getPAsymptomaticSymptomatic(), SymptomState.SYMPTOMATIC
297                                ).orElse(SymptomState.ASYMPTOMATIC);
298                                return SymptomState.ASYMPTOMATIC;
299                        case SYMPTOMATIC:
300                                return rng.multinom(
301                                                Pair.of(
302                                                                this.getPSymptomaticAsymptomatic(),
303                                                                SymptomState.ASYMPTOMATIC
304                                                ),
305                                                Pair.of(
306                                                                this.getPSymptomaticHospitalised(),
307                                                                SymptomState.HOSPITALISED
308                                                ), Pair.of(this.getPSymptomaticDead(), SymptomState.DEAD)
309                                ).orElse(SymptomState.SYMPTOMATIC);
310                        case HOSPITALISED:
311                                return rng.multinom(
312                                                Pair.of(
313                                                                this.getPHospitalisedAsymptomatic(),
314                                                                SymptomState.ASYMPTOMATIC
315                                                ), Pair.of(this.getPHospitalisedDead(), SymptomState.DEAD)
316                                ).orElse(SymptomState.HOSPITALISED);
317                        case DEAD:
318                                return SymptomState.DEAD;
319                        default:
320                                throw new RuntimeException();
321                        }
322                }
323        }
324
325        /**
326         * The clinical symptom progression states.
327         *
328         * <p>
329         * These represent observable health outcomes: \[ \text{ASYMPTOMATIC}
330         * \xrightarrow{p_s} \text{SYMPTOMATIC} \xrightarrow{p_h,p_d}
331         * \text{HOSPITALISED} \xrightarrow{p_{hd}} \text{DEAD} \] with possible
332         * regression to less severe states (e.g., recovery). The symptom state is
333         * conditional on disease state and evolves independently.
334         */
335        public static enum SymptomState {
336                /**
337                 * The individual is infected but shows no symptoms. They can transition
338                 * to SYMPTOMATIC with probability \( p_s \) if they are in the INFECTIOUS
339                 * disease state, or remain ASYMPTOMATIC if they do not develop symptoms.
340                 * This state captures subclinical infections that may still contribute to
341                 * transmission.
342                 */
343                ASYMPTOMATIC,
344                /**
345                 * The individual is infected and shows symptoms. They can transition to
346                 * HOSPITALISED if symptoms worsen, or to ASYMPTOMATIC if they recover.
347                 * This state represents the period of symptomatic illness.
348                 */
349                SYMPTOMATIC,
350                /**
351                 * The individual is infected and has severe symptoms requiring
352                 * hospitalisation. They can transition to DEAD if they deteriorate, or to
353                 * ASYMPTOMATIC if they recover. This state captures severe clinical
354                 * outcomes.
355                 */
356                HOSPITALISED,
357                /**
358                 * The individual has died from the infection. This is an absorbing state
359                 * with no transitions out. It represents the most severe outcome of the
360                 * disease.
361                 */
362                DEAD
363
364        }
365
366        /**
367         * Getters for the current disease and symptom states, and the Markov state
368         * machine.
369         *
370         * <p>
371         * These provide access to the individual's current position in the disease
372         * and symptom progression, as well as the transition probabilities defined
373         * in the Markov model. The disease and symptom states evolve independently
374         * according to their respective transition rules, but are both influenced by
375         * the underlying MarkovStateMachine which governs the probabilities of
376         * moving between states.
377         *
378         * @return the current disease state, symptom state, and Markov state machine
379         */
380        DiseaseState getDiseaseState();
381
382        /**
383         * Returns immune activity as a binary indicator.
384         *
385         * <p>
386         * Defined as: \[ I(t) = \begin{cases} 1.0 &amp; \text{if } \text{disease
387         * state} = \text{IMMUNE} \\ 0.0 &amp; \text{otherwise} \end{cases} \] This
388         * reflects full protection during the immune state, with no partial
389         * immunity.
390         *
391         * @return 1.0 if immune, 0.0 otherwise
392         */
393        @Override
394        default double getImmuneActivity() {
395                return this.getDiseaseState().equals(DiseaseState.IMMUNE) ? 1D : 0D;
396        }
397
398        /**
399         * Returns the infection-case rate (ICR) for this individual, which is the
400         * probability of developing symptoms given infection.
401         *
402         * @return the infection-case rate (ICR) for this individual
403         */
404        double getInfectionCaseRate();
405
406        /**
407         * Returns the infection-fatality rate (IFR) for this individual, which is
408         * the probability of death given infection.
409         *
410         * @return the infection-fatality rate (IFR) for this individual
411         */
412        double getInfectionFatalityRate();
413
414        /**
415         * Returns the infection-hospitalization rate (IHR) for this individual,
416         * which is the probability of hospitalization given infection.
417         *
418         * @return the infection-hospitalization rate (IHR) for this individual
419         */
420        double getInfectionHospitalisationRate();
421
422        /**
423         * Returns the Markov state machine that defines the transition probabilities
424         * for both disease and symptom progression. This machine encapsulates the
425         * time-homogeneous transition rates between states, allowing for calibration
426         * from epidemiological data. The transition probabilities govern how
427         * individuals move through the disease states (e.g., from EXPOSED to
428         * INFECTIOUS) and symptom states (e.g., from ASYMPTOMATIC to SYMPTOMATIC) on
429         * a daily basis. The machine's methods are used in the update logic to
430         * determine the next state based on the current state and random sampling.
431         *
432         * @return the Markov state machine containing transition probabilities for
433         *         disease and symptom progression
434         * @see InHostMarkovStateMachine
435         *
436         */
437        @Value.Redacted
438        InHostMarkovStateMachine getMachine();
439
440        /**
441         * Samples a continuous severity score from a uniform distribution based on
442         * symptom state.
443         *
444         * <p>
445         * The score is calibrated so that:
446         * <ul>
447         * <li>Case rate: \( \mathbb{P}(S \gt 1 - r_c) = r_c \),</li>
448         * <li>Hospitalization rate: \( \mathbb{P}(S \gt 1 - r_h) = r_h \),</li>
449         * <li>Fatality rate: \( \mathbb{P}(S \gt 1 - r_f) = r_f \),</li>
450         * </ul>
451         * where \( r_c, r_h, r_f \) are the infection-case,
452         * infection-hospitalization, and infection-fatality ratios.
453         *
454         * <p>
455         * For example: \[ S \sim \text{Uniform}(1 - r_h, 1 - r_f) \quad \text{if }
456         * \text{HOSPITALISED} \] This ensures the population-level event rates match
457         * input parameters.
458         *
459         * @return a sampled severity value in [0,1]
460         */
461        @Override @Value.Derived
462        default double getNormalisedSeverity() {
463                Sampler rng = Sampler.getSampler();
464                switch (this.getSymptomState()) {
465                case ASYMPTOMATIC:
466                        if (!this.getDiseaseState().equals(DiseaseState.INFECTIOUS)) return 0;
467                        return rng.uniform(0, 1 - this.getInfectionCaseRate());
468                case SYMPTOMATIC:
469                        return rng.uniform(
470                                        1 - this.getInfectionCaseRate(),
471                                        1 - this.getInfectionHospitalisationRate()
472                        );
473                case HOSPITALISED:
474                        return rng.uniform(
475                                        1 - this.getInfectionHospitalisationRate(),
476                                        1 - this.getInfectionFatalityRate()
477                        );
478                case DEAD:
479                        return rng.uniform(1 - this.getInfectionFatalityRate(), 1);
480                default:
481                        throw new RuntimeException();
482                }
483        }
484
485        /**
486         * Returns a fixed normalized viral load based on disease state.
487         *
488         * <p>
489         * Defined as: \[ V_{\text{norm}} = \begin{cases} 1.5 &amp; \text{if }
490         * \text{state} = \text{INFECTIOUS} \\ 0.5 &amp; \text{if } \text{state} =
491         * \text{EXPOSED} \\ 0.0 &amp; \text{otherwise} \end{cases} \] This coarse
492         * proxy enables transmission modeling without detailed viral kinetics.
493         *
494         * @return a state-dependent normalized viral load
495         */
496        @Override
497        default double getNormalisedViralLoad() {
498                if (this.getDiseaseState().equals(DiseaseState.INFECTIOUS)) return 1.5D;
499                if (this.getDiseaseState().equals(DiseaseState.EXPOSED)) return 0.5D;
500                return 0D;
501        }
502
503        /**
504         * The symptom state is conditional on the disease state, but evolves
505         * independently according to its own transition probabilities defined in the
506         * MarkovStateMachine. For example, an individual may be in the INFECTIOUS
507         * disease state but remain ASYMPTOMATIC in terms of symptoms, and then
508         * transition to SYMPTOMATIC based on the probability defined for that
509         * transition. The symptom progression is thus a separate layer of the model
510         * that captures clinical outcomes without directly affecting the underlying
511         * disease state transitions.
512         *
513         * @return the current symptom state of the individual
514         */
515        SymptomState getSymptomState();
516
517        // MarkovStateModel getConfig();
518        /**
519         * Returns the current time step in the in-host progression.
520         *
521         * @return the current time step (e.g., days since infection) in the in-host
522         *         progression
523         */
524        @Override
525        int getTime();
526
527        /**
528         * Advances the in-host state by one time step using Markov transitions.
529         *
530         * <p>
531         * The update logic:
532         * <ol>
533         * <li>If currently SUSCEPTIBLE and exposed to virions: → EXPOSED,</li>
534         * <li>If currently SUSCEPTIBLE and immunized: → IMMUNE,</li>
535         * <li>Otherwise: apply Markov transitions from current disease and symptom
536         * states.</li>
537         * </ol>
538         *
539         * <p>
540         * Disease progression uses Bernoulli and multinomial sampling: \[
541         * \mathbb{P}(X_{t+1} = x') = \sum_{x} \mathbb{P}(X_t = x) \cdot p(x \to x')
542         * \] where transition probabilities are constant per day.
543         *
544         * <p>
545         * The use of {@link Sampler#bern(Double, Object)} and
546         * {@link Sampler#multinom(Pair...)} ensures independent stochastic
547         * realizations. The sum of such independent transitions aligns with the
548         * framework of the <i>Poisson binomial distribution</i> when aggregating
549         * over populations, where each individual has a potentially different path
550         * through the state space.
551         *
552         * @param sampler          the random sampler for stochastic transitions
553         * @param virionExposure   non-zero if the individual is exposed to
554         *                         infectious virions
555         * @param immunisationDose non-zero if the individual receives an immunizing
556         *                         dose (e.g., vaccine)
557         * @return a new state advanced by one time unit
558         */
559        @Override
560        default InHostMarkovState update(
561                        Sampler sampler, double virionExposure, double immunisationDose
562        ) {
563
564                DiseaseState next;
565                if (this.getDiseaseState().equals(DiseaseState.SUSCEPTIBLE)) {
566                        if (virionExposure > 0) {
567//                              if (this.getMachine().getPExposedInfectious() == 1.0) {
568//                                      //Skip E if E->I duration is zero => pTransition = 1.
569//                                      next = DiseaseState.INFECTIOUS;
570//                              } else {
571                                next = DiseaseState.EXPOSED;
572//                              }
573                        } else if (immunisationDose > 0) {
574                                next = DiseaseState.IMMUNE;
575                        } else {
576                                next = this.getMachine()
577                                                .updateDiseaseState(this.getDiseaseState(), sampler);
578                        }
579                } else {
580                        next = this.getMachine()
581                                        .updateDiseaseState(this.getDiseaseState(), sampler);
582                }
583
584                Builder builder = ImmutableInHostMarkovState.builder().from(this);
585                return builder.setDiseaseState(next)
586                                .setSymptomState(
587                                                this.getMachine().updateSymptomState(
588                                                                this.getSymptomState(), this.getDiseaseState(), sampler
589                                                )
590                                ).setTime(this.getTime() + 1).build();
591
592        }
593
594}
